awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation of students in the sixth GREPSEC workshop, held August 7-8 2023 in conjunction with the USENIX Security Conference.  GREPSEC promotes increased engagement in computer security research, specifically targeting women and underrepresented groups through mentorship. The goals of the workshop are to increase diversity in the field.  Prior GREPSEC attendees have gone on to publish in a range of venues, mostly focused on the field of cybersecurity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes Report, GREPSEC ‘23, Federal Award ID 2331050

This award provided conference funding covering event direct costs and student travel costs for the G/rep{sec} (GREPSEC, or Underrepresented Groups in Security Research) Workshop held on August 8, 2023, in Anaheim, California. It was the sixth GREPSEC Workshop.

The number of women and minorities is low overall in computer science, a situation reflected in the specific security field. According to a 2022 update by Davide Balzarotti of his “System Security Circus,” of all papers published between 2000 and 2020 in four prominent security conferences (specifically, IEEE S&P, USENIX Security, NDSS, ACM CSS), women accounted for only 13.8% of all researchers represented. GREPSEC VI promoted increased engagement in computer security research by groups historically excluded from technology, and specifically security-focused, careers.

Facilitated by researchers and speakers from underrepresented groups who are already in the field, the workshop demonstrated the wide range of problems faced by these groups working in security research. It also identified some attempted solutions, and provided examples of successful researchers who represent the experiences of participants. 

Participants were selected through an application process open to all computer science students, with a strong emphasis on students at the Ph.D. level interested in the security and privacy field. We considered students not enrolled at U.S.-based universities but funded their participation through non-NSF funds. To ensure a robust field of applicants, we advertised through mailing lists associated with USENIX Association and previous GREPSEC mail lists, systers, Latinas and Black Women in Computing, as well as through social media outreach and promotion at side events during the 2023 IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy. We also shared the opportunity with computer science departments at Minority-Serving Institutions, including Historically Black Colleges and Universities. 

Student participants were primarily mid-career Ph.D. students with some exceptions to involve younger Ph.D. students, MS students, undergrads who are very involved in research, and a few senior Ph.D. students. After reviewing applications, we invited 43 students to attend. Two of these missed the workshop due to illness, and one was unable to procure a visa in time. In total, 40 students attended, 35 of whom were directly supported through NSF funds.

GREPSEC VI provided multiple benefits for participating students during its day-long program. They took part in interactive sessions that allowed them to explore the security field in a space dedicated to that purpose and therefore safe for intellectual curiosity. In particular, for those considering a specialization in security, participation provided an opportunity for a focused examination of the subject matter to inform decision-making.

The agenda (https://www.usenix.org/conference/grepsecvi/workshop-program) consisted of four talks led by prominent researchers in the security and privacy field who also represented historically excluded groups. Speakers were selected in part based on their ability to actively engage with student participants in this capacity. Each talk was followed by a question and answer period, allowing student participants to engage directly with those researchers. The agenda also included breakout sessions that allowed participants to engage with each other, the speakers, and other subject matter experts more informally. The informal nature of the workshop further fostered new and strengthened connections among student participants, speakers, and organizers, thereby enhancing the supportive and enabling social environment for prospective security researchers as they embark on this career path. 

The GREPSEC VI agenda ended with a session of speed mentoring that connected the participating students with another cadre of researchers in the field for intensive one-on-one discussions. After the formal conclusion of the workshop, all GREPSEC VI participants were included in an evening event held in the same venue by the Center for Privacy and Security for Marginalized and Vulnerable Populations (PRISM), an opportunity for expanded informal networking within the field. Also, the USENIX Association prioritized GREPSEC attendees for student grants to cover the registration cost of USENIX Security ‘23, which began the day following the GREPSEC VI Workshop, further enabling the participants to immerse themselves in the privacy and security community while increasing diversity among those attendees.

Most of the funds committed with this award were spent on participant support costs that covered the travel costs of 35 of the student attendees. The remainder of the attending students had travel grants that came from their own institutions or through sponsors. The remaining value of the NSF award was spent on other direct workshop costs, including registration costs, internet, audio-visual equipment and services, and catering. Non-NSF funds also contributed to GREPSEC workshop costs.
